events.name: Friday Hacks #146: Editor War
events.description:
Hey Hackers, Friday Hacks is back again to kick-start the semester! What better way to start the semester than to learn about productivity hacks! We’ll attempt to tackle the age-old question: Vim or Emacs?

Our very own Jethro and Herbert will be sharing with us some ways that Emacs or Vim has made them more productive. Attend the talk to know more!

Editor War: Vim

Talk Description:
Vim is a powerful text editor available in most Unix/Linux machines. It is an extended version of the vi editor, with many additional features designed to be helpful in editing program source code. Like vi, it is a modal editor: it operates in different modes, such as insert mode, normal mode, or visual mode. There are many plugins available for Vim that extends or add new functionality to Vim. Some notable programmers that use Vim are Larry Wall who created the Perl programming language, Paul Graham, and Charlie Cheever, the co-founder of Quora.

Speaker Profile
Herbert is a Year 3 Computer Science student who has been using vim for 2 years. It has made him more productive because of all the mnemonical shortcuts as well as plugins that made doing a lot of things easier.

Editor War: Emacs

Talk Description:
Emacs is a text editor that is characterized by its extensibility. Emacs has over 10,000 built-in commands and its user interface allows the user to combine these commands into macros to automate work. Emacs uses its own dialect of lisp called Emacs Lisp, which is used for implementing most of the editing functionality built into Emacs. Some notable programmers that use emacs are Richard Stallman, Guido van Rossum who created the Python programming language, and Mark Zuckerberg.

Speaker Profile
Jethro is a Year 2 Computer Science student who has been using Emacs for about 2 years now. He previously used vim for 5 years but made the switch because he says he is as good as his tools and he reached a point where vim doesn’t cut it anymore.
events.location: Seminar Room 3, NUS School of Computing (COM1-0212), , Singapore

events.name: Resumes, Interviews & Branding
events.description: Writing a resume/CV or going for a interview for a Tech job can be quite different. To stand out from the crowd, it is necessary to brand yourself, and create your own unique signature. Join us for an evening of fun where WWCode is collaborating with X-pand and WTM (Women Techmakers) to provide insights on how to do all these. Agenda:6:30 PM: Registration & Food7:00 PM: Introductions7:10 PM: Personal Branding (Georgina Parker)7:30 PM: Interview Workshop (Charlotte Park & Michelle Tan)7:50 PM: Q&A Panel8:30 PM: Wrap Up This event is open to everyone who is there to inspire women to excel in tech careers. First name and last name is required for entry to Google.Please fill up this from:https://goo.gl/forms/5FWQWl4mWDr2QWp53 All attendees kindly read and abide by the Women Who Code Code of Conduct - https://github.com/WomenWhoCode/guidelines-resources/blob/master/code_of_conduct.md Sponsor:Google's Women Techmakers Brought to you in collaboration with:Women Techmakers and X-pand
events.location: Google Asia Pacific, 70, Pasir Panjang Road, #03-71, Mapletree Business City, Singapore 117371

events.name: There Is A Service For That! with Mayur Tendulkar (PM on Xamarin@Microsoft)
events.description: • What we'll doThe awesome Mayur will be representing team Xamarin at the Microsoft Tech Summit SG (https://www.microsoft.com/en-sg/techsummit/singapore) and will especially host a session at our beloved Xamarin SG user group. There Is A Service For That! (Level 200) Description:Unless it is a static app, every mobile app requires services. E.g. it needs service to authenticate with social networks or Active Directory of the organization, service to store or retrieve data from somewhere, service to send notifications to the user or service to report app crashes. Join Mayur Tendulkar from Microsoft to know about these services and how you can take benefit of these services. About Mayur:Mayur Tendulkar is Program Manager on Xamarin team at Microsoft, working from Pune, India. Before joining Microsoft, since 2013, he was awarded as Microsoft Most Valuable Professional on Windows Development and worked as Developer Evangelist with Xamarin. He is writing mobile applications since the days of Windows Mobile 5.0 and love to talk about everything mobile. You can find him talking at conferences, user groups and on various social channels. His co-ordinates are @mayur_Tendulkar and for git: mayur-tendulkar. You can follow his thoughts on his blog: http://mayurtendulkar.com Schedule:18:45 Registration / Pizza19:00 Mayur Live!21:00 Curfew • Important to knowThere will be pizza!
